author: By Alex Marshall
title: Keeper of a Painter’s Secrets? Or a Fantasist and a Trickster?
description: Barry Joule says his friend Francis Bacon gave him a trove of sketches and paintings. Some experts aren’t so sure.
content: The last time Barry Joule saw his friend Francis Bacon, it was 10 days before the celebrated painter’s death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Colby Smith
title: A Key Interest Rate Falls, but Not for the Reasons Trump Wanted
description: Investors’ increasingly gloomy sentiment about economic growth appears to be driving down the 10-year Treasury yield.
content: President Trump campaigned on a promise to bring down interest rates. And he has fulfilled that pledge in one key way, with U.S. government bond yields falling sharply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Seeing Political Red Meat, Texas May Rename the New York Strip Steak
description: The Texas strip? That state’s lieutenant governor wants to rebrand the cut, but New Yorkers aren’t biting.
content: Nobody knows exactly how long ago a marbled and tender boneless short-loin steak came to be known across the United States as a New York strip. Everybody agrees, though, that the nomenclature wasn’t the least bit controversial until last Friday, when Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick of Texas proposed a new name: the Texas strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Anora’ Wins Best Picture During a Dominant Night at the Oscars
description: For his movie about an exotic dancer who weds a Russian heir, Sean Baker won awards for best director, original screenplay and editing.
content: “Anora,” a comedy-drama about an exotic dancer who weds a flighty Russian, won best picture at the Oscars on Sunday night, capping a dominant performance for a movie that was far from a box-office smash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Conan O’Brien’s Monologue: Little Roasting, No Politics, Very Silly
description: The host evoked some of his delightfully experimental bits from his old late-night show.
content: Conan O’Brien brought the bizarre back to Oscar hosting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dmytro Kuleba
title: This Is Europe’s War Now
description: Ukraine wants a peace deal — it just doesn’t want to end up destroyed by peace’s terms.
content: On Friday, after a grim-faced Volodymyr Zelensky departed the White House, President Trump wrote on social media that the Ukrainian leader could “come back when he is ready for Peace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Emily Badger and Jeremy Singer-Vine
title: Struggling With Errors, DOGE Deletes Billions More From List of Savings
description: For the second time in a week, Elon Musk’s government overhaul effort updated its “wall of receipts” to remove mistakes that inflated its success.
content: Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency has deleted hundreds more claims from its mistake-plagued “wall of receipts,” erasing $4 billion in additional savings that the group said it had made for U.S. taxpayers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in March
description: New arrivals for U.S. subscribers include a sweeping adaptation of a literary classic and a quirky science-fiction movie starring Millie Bobby Brown.
content: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of March’s most promising new titles for subscribers in the United States. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy, Tressie McMillan Cottom and Vishakha Darbha
title: What Man’s Man Politics Is Doing to America
description: And why Democrats shouldn’t try to “out-cowboy” Donald Trump.
content: President Trump’s outsize performance of masculinity has won him attention, elections and the support of manosphere influencers from Andrew Tate to Joe Rogan. In this episode of “The Opinions,” the deputy editor of Times Opinion, Patrick Healy, speaks with columnist Tressie McMillan Cottom about what Trump’s focus on gender means for men, women, minorities and American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, William K. Rashbaum and Devlin Barrett
title: Top New York City F.B.I. Agent Forced Out After Clash With Justice Dept.
description: James E. Dennehy had told agents to “dig in” in the face of the Trump administration’s culling of officials who investigated the Jan. 6 attack.
content: The top agent at the F.B.I.’s New York field office said in an email Monday that he had been forced out of his job, following clashes with Justice Department officials over Trump administration directives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: On Oscars Night, More Celebrities Tried the Nearly Nude Look
description: Julia Fox followed up Bianca Censori’s much-discussed Grammys moment with a sheer dress at Vanity Fair’s party. Others joined her in the less-is-more approach.
content: About a month after Bianca Censori caused a commotion for posing on the red carpet at the Grammy Awards in a completely sheer minidress, another woman with ties to Ye arrived in a similarly nearly naked look to Vanity Fair’s Oscars after-party on Sunday. This time, it was Julia Fox, who previously dated the rapper and designer formerly known as Kanye West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Zoe Saldaña Wins Best Supporting Actress Oscar for ‘Emilia Pérez’
description: Saldaña anchors “El Mal,” which won the Oscar for best original song, in the Spanish-language musical.
content: Zoe Saldaña won the Academy Award for best supporting actress for her performance in the Spanish-language musical “Emilia Pérez.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and Mark Landler
title: The Scramble After a White House Showdown, and R.F.K. Jr.’s Measles Response
description: Plus, “Anora” has a big night at the Oscars.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: A.I. Start-Up Anthropic Closes Deal That Values It at $61.5 Billion
description: The announcement follows new fund-raising efforts from rivals like OpenAI, which is set to close a deal that values the company at $300 billion, and Elon Musk’s xAI.
content: The artificial intelligence start-up Anthropic said on Monday that it had completed a new fund-raising deal that valued the company at $61.5 billion, up from about $16 billion a little more than a year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca F. Elliott
title: Oil Prices Fall After OPEC Plus Affirms Plan to Raise Production
description: The Saudi-led cartel said its members would start gradually pumping more oil in April.
content: Oil prices fell on Monday afternoon to their lowest level of the year after the OPEC oil cartel and its allies affirmed plans to gradually increase crude production beginning in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Jack Vettriano, ‘Singing Butler’ Painter, Dies at 73
description: Critics largely rejected his work, but when it was last sold in 2004, “The Singing Butler” was the most valuable piece of art to ever emerge from Scotland.
content: Jack Vettriano, a self-taught Scottish painter best known for “The Singing Butler,” who overcame critical derision to become one of the best selling painters in Europe, has died. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: The Details That Make the Vienna Philharmonic Like No Other Orchestra
description: Riccardo Muti, in what felt like a victory lap, returned to Carnegie Hall to lead the Philharmonic’s annual three-day series of concerts.
content: Bow down to the Vienna Philharmonic’s tremolo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: ‘No Other Land,’ Whose Politics Deterred Distributors, Wins Best Documentary
description: In their acceptance speeches, the Israeli and Palestinian co-directors called for “serious actions to stop the injustice.”
content: Accepting the Oscar for best documentary feature on Sunday night, two filmmakers behind “No Other Land,” which chronicles Israeli demolitions of Palestinian homes in the southern West Bank, called on the world to work to help halt the “ethnic cleansing” of Palestinians, free the remaining Israeli hostages captured in “the crime of Oct. 7” and chart a more equitable path forward for Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Kemeny
title: What a Crab Sees Before It Gets Eaten by a Cuttlefish
description: Cuttlefish use visual tricks to avoid being eaten. New research shows how they deploy similar camouflage to bamboozle their prey.
content: In May 2023, Matteo Santon was filming cuttlefish in the shallow-water reefs around Indonesia. A marine visual ecologist at Bristol University in England, he planned to document the predators’ approach to hunting from the perspective of the prey — essentially, to see what it’s like to be the crab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Social Security and Sex Robots: Musk Veers Off Script With Joe Rogan
description: Elon Musk’s three-hour interview with “The Joe Rogan Experience” offered a window into his worldview that was by turns crude and contradictory.
content: As President Trump sets about shrinking the government, he has repeatedly claimed that popular safety net programs, including Social Security and Medicaid, are off the table, and spoken about them delicately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Bright, Effortless Soup Is Exactly What I Need Right Now
description: After months of heavy stews and deep casseroles, my light, bright lemony carrot and cauliflower soup hits just right.
content: We caught a glimpse of spring this past week here in New York City, when the sun busted out and temperatures flirted with, though couldn’t quite commit to, the 60s. Chilling rain has returned, but the brief respite proved that spring will be back. Eventually. Meantime, let’s talk soup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amancai Biraben and Stella Kalinina
title: After the Fires, Los Angeles Becomes Even Tougher for New Buyers
description: With fierce competition and less inventory, potential buyers are bracing for a fight or wondering if they will have to leave the city to become homeowners.
content: This was supposed to be the year that Joel Cruz and his family would buy a house. The owner of a popular taco truck catering business called Oaxaca on Wheels, Mr. Cruz had begun to look in the West Adams neighborhood of Los Angeles, where his family has rented an apartment for the past 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 21 Unforgettable Looks at the Oscars
description: Tiered gowns, buttery suits, tuxedo dresses and more.
content: The 97th Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday was the end of an awards season that lost some of its luster because of tragic wildfires and controversies surrounding certain nominated films. But, for the most part, the heaviness in the air did not dim the sparkle of the season’s red carpets — and the custom “Academy Red” rug that stars paraded down at the Oscars was no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Laura Sessions Stepp, Who Reported on Teenage Sex, Dies at 73
description: A Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, she went on to write about “hookup culture” and young women’s sexual experiences for The Washington Post and in a best-selling book.
content: Laura Sessions Stepp, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist whose reporting on teenage sex and “hookup” culture on college campuses explored in strikingly intimate detail how adolescent girls and young women think about relationships, love and bodily autonomy, died on Feb. 24 in Springfield, Va. She was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Timothée Chalamet Keeps It Playful in Buttery Suit
description: The best actor nominee made a series of memorable arrivals this awards season, but he let his Givenchy suit do the talking on Sunday.
content: Timothée Chalamet’s sartorial playfulness has been a consistent theme as he stepped out in memorable looks for each red carpet event over the last few months. For the Oscars, the most conservative red carpet of them all, he did not disappoint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Paul Tazewell Becomes First Black Man to Win for Costume Design
description: He won for his work on the Broadway musical adaptation “Wicked.”
content: Paul Tazewell became the first Black man to win the Oscar for best costume design Sunday. Honored for his work on the Broadway musical adaptation “Wicked,” Tazewell stepped to the dais and said, “I am the first Black man to receive the costume design award.” The remark prompted a standing ovation as Tazewell continued with his brief acceptance speech, in which he thanked “my Oz-ian muses, Cynthia and Ariana,” referring to the actresses Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: TSMC, the Chip Giant, Is to Spend $100 Billion in U.S. Over the Next 4 Years
description: The investment plan, announced at the White House, was made as the Trump administration pushes to bring chip making back to the United States.
content: President Trump on Monday said Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world’s largest chip manufacturer, will spend $100 billion in the United States over the next four years to expand its production capacity and bring its most advanced semiconductor processes to its operations in Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: Your Workout Should Hurt. But When Is Pain a Red Flag?
description: Here’s how to know whether it’s safe to push through.
content: It’s 6:15 a.m. and you are five minutes into your first run in weeks. The temperature is perfect and the sun is just emerging, turning the sky into a stained glass masterpiece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Thinking About Menopause Hormone Therapy? Start Here.
description: Anxiety around the treatment persists, but so does recent enthusiasm. Here’s what experts want you to know.
content: At Dr. Monica Christmas’s clinic these days, she sees two kinds of menopausal patients. The first, she said, is suffering from the symptoms associated with this life phase, but is also wary of hormone therapy because she’s heard there are health risks associated with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Zelensky Turns to Diplomacy in a War With ‘a Long Way to Go’
description: After a startling clash with President Trump, who has echoed the Kremlin view of the war, Ukraine’s leader is trying to shore up European support and smooth over relations with Washington.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky returned to Ukraine on Monday after a whirlwind diplomatic mission that included both humiliation, by President Trump, and a warm embrace, from European leaders. He vowed to use all diplomatic avenues to pursue an end to Ukraine’s war with Russia, but acknowledged there was “a long way to go.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: That’s a Weird Thing to Lie About
description: Unnecessary and outrageous falsehoods.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 3, 2025
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 3, 2025.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Tesla for Sale: Buyer’s Remorse Sinks In for Elon Musk’s E.V.-Owning Critics
description: The backlash against the electric vehicle company has intensified as the billionaire ally of President Trump exerts his power over the federal government.
content: When Jennifer Trebb first pulled into her driveway two years ago with her sleek Tesla Model Y, it was — as she put it — “kind of like a ‘Back to the Future’ moment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Sean Baker Wins Best Director for ‘Anora’ and Ties a Record Set by Walt Disney
description: By winning the Oscars for director, original screenplay, film editing and best picture (as a producer), he tied the record for most Oscars won by an individual in one year.
content: Whoever won the prize for best director on Sunday night was going to receive a first directing Oscar, but no nominee has labored as a filmmaker more single-mindedly for a longer time than Sean Baker, the creative force behind “Anora.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Teacher Whose Sex Crime Arrest Shook an N.Y.C. Prep School Pleads Guilty
description: Winston Nguyen, who taught math at Saint Ann’s School in Brooklyn, was accused of soliciting lewd images from students. He pleaded guilty to a felony and five misdemeanors.
content: When one of New York City’s most prestigious private schools hired Winston Nguyen in 2020, administrators knew about the felony conviction for fraud in his troubled past. But the second chance they offered him backfired. Nearly four years later, Mr. Nguyen, a math teacher, was arrested again, accused of preying on students. And the school, Saint Ann’s in Brooklyn, faced a roiling crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Gazans Worry as Israeli Border Block Sends Food Prices Climbing
description: The halt on aid and commercial goods was intended to put pressure on Hamas, but it is already having a broader effect, Palestinians say.
content: One day after Israel began halting the entry of all goods and humanitarian assistance into the Gaza Strip, Palestinians there are already feeling the effects of the sweeping measure, with prices of essential goods on the rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Ian Austen
title: What’s Behind Trump’s Love-Hate Relationship With Canada
description: Canada is one of the United States’ largest trading partners, but President Trump wants to either take it or leave it.
content: There is the theory that President Trump is still bitter about his Canadian hotel ventures that went bust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: U.S.A.I.D. Memos Detail Human Costs of Cuts to Foreign Aid
description: The world is likely to see millions more malaria infections and 200,000 cases of paralytic polio each year, according to an agency whistle-blower.
content: The Trump administration’s decision to withdraw foreign aid and dismantle the U.S. Agency for International Development is likely to cause enormous human suffering, according to estimates by the agency itself. Among them:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: He’s the Face of a White House Press Corps Under Attack by Trump
description: Eugene Daniels, president of the White House Correspondents’ Association, is pushing back on the administration’s hostility to reporters as he navigates a move to MSNBC from Politico.
content: Eugene Daniels didn’t plan on being the face of the White House press corps in the dawn of a new administration hostile to the news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Bennett
title: When ‘We’ Becomes ‘I’: The Case for Divorce
description: Two new memoirs show the commonalities — and differences — in the end of every marriage.
content: I can’t recall the first time I saw “The Misfits,” John Huston’s 1961 cinematic masterpiece about a quartet of mutually disenfranchised wanderers, but I’m certain it was after I’d become a divorcée. I know it wouldn’t have stuck with me so permanently otherwise. Set in Reno, Nev., a city once as famous for its hassle-free divorces as its casinos, the film is a timeless meditation on what it means to lose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Alejandro Cegarra
title: On Mexico’s Once-Packed Border, Few Migrants Remain
description: There has been a dramatic drop in the number of people gathering at the U.S. border and trying to cross. Can it help Mexico stave off President Trump’s threatened tariffs?
content: On the eve of President Trump’s deadline to impose tariffs on Mexico, one thing is hard to miss on the Mexican side of the border: The migrants are gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Old-Fashioned Train Heists Yield Modern-Day Loot: Nike Air Jordans
description: Transnational gangs have been targeting sneakers, wireless gaming headsets and other modern merchandise transported by rail, according to federal prosecutors.
content: It sounds like something out of the Wild West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Lam
title: How to Be an American Carpenter in Japan? Don’t Take ‘No’ for an Answer
description: Following the advice of Zen masters, Jon Stollenmeyer endured months of rejection before finally getting his foot in the sliding door.
content: Jon Stollenmeyer, 42, grew up in Ohio and studied architecture at the University of Cincinnati. In 2005, he visited a classmate in Japan with the idea of seeing the work of modern architects like Tadao Ando and Kengo Kuma. He soon revised his itinerary when he encountered the country’s antique temples, farmhouses and teahouses and became infatuated with Japanese wood architecture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: 2 Troubled Carmakers, Nissan and Stellantis, Could Be Hit Hardest by Tariffs
description: A possible 25 percent levy on goods from Canada and Mexico is likely to raise the prices consumers pay for new cars and trucks, and disrupt complex supply chains.
content: Nissan Motor has suffered several setbacks in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Mikey Madison Wins the Best Lead Actress Oscar for ‘Anora’
description: Madison, who played a tenacious sex worker, called the win “a dream come true.” She beat Demi Moore, widely considered a favorite, for the award.
content: Mikey Madison, who played a feisty and tenacious sex worker in the movie “Anora,” won the Oscar for best lead actress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Danielle Kaye
title: Stocks Post Biggest Loss of the Year on Trump’s Tariff Plans
description: The S&P 500 fell 1.8 percent on Monday after President Trump doubled down on plans to impose 25 percent tariffs on Canada and Mexico starting Tuesday.
content: Stocks fell sharply on Monday afternoon after President Trump affirmed tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico, dashing investors’ hopes of a last-minute reprieve and intensifying concern that the sweeping tariffs could hit corporate profits and fuel inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump and the Press
description: The president wants journalists to parrot his views and face consequences if they don’t.
content: President Trump has spent years demonizing the press. He popularized the phrase “fake news” and branded journalists the “enemy of the people.” He frequently sues news outlets. His administration is investigating broadcasters. Trump and his followers falsely claim that news organizations, including The Times, are bankrolled by the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why Is Everything Dry-Clean Only Now?
description: In response to a reader who has noticed more and more dry-clean-only labels on clothing, our critic explains why they are increasing and how to properly wash clothes.
content: In truth, I think the ubiquity of the dry-cleaning label is less about a conspiracy between fashion and launderers and more about fashion companies watching their backs. How to wash clothes, especially special clothes, is one of those skills that became … well, unfashionable back in the middle of the last century, when home ec classes went the way of the dodo.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Undoing Years of Climate Policy in a Few Weeks
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 2, 2025.
content: “This is not the kind of stately tennis match of the usual switch-over in administrations. This is full on ‘Fight Club.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schabas
title: This ‘Swan Lake’ Keeps the Tutus but Sheds the Tights
description: Barelegged swans are a bit like baseball players without caps. But as the art form confronts its history of racial homogeneity some traditions are being rethought.
content: At first glance, the 24 swans fluttering across the stage at the Four Seasons Center for the Performing Arts in Toronto look as traditional as they come. Their tutus form stiff rings of tulle around their hips. Bodices are adorned with bright white plumage, heads wrapped in feathery wreaths that cover both ears. Arms ripple up and down, the line breaking at the wrist to suggest the curved edge of a wing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Kieran Culkin Wins the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor
description: The victory for his role in “A Real Pain” completes a dominant awards season.
content: Kieran Culkin won the Academy Award for best supporting actor for his role as the descendant of a Holocaust survivor who makes a family pilgrimage to Poland in the dramatic comedy of manners “A Real Pain.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Rising Temperatures Are Scrambling the Base of the Ocean Food Web
description: Scientists are gaining new insights into how plankton supports life on Earth — just as climate change is changing everything.
content: Humans are living in a plankton world. These minuscule organisms are spread across the oceans, covering nearly three-quarters of the planet, and are among the most abundant forms of life on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Cuomo’s In, and It’s a Whole New Mayor’s Race
description: Former Gov. Andrew Cuomo benefits from name recognition but also carries a fair amount of baggage.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at how former Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s announcement that he would run for mayor of New York could complicate the chances of the Democrats who are already in the race — including Mayor Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Tilting Away From the Tux
description: At last night’s Oscars the men who skipped the penguin suits stole the spotlight. Stylists and brands should pay attention.
content: If you wish to fully grasp Timothée Chalamet’s Oscars suit, you may do better to consult a food reporter rather than a fashion critic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sinna Nasseri
title: Our Favorite Photos From the Oscars Red Carpet
description: The show before the show, aglitter with stars and fashion, is also home to tender moments you don’t always see.
content: “Anora” won big at the 97th Academy Awards on Sunday night, nabbing best picture and several other categories. Before all that, as the stars arrived at the Dolby Theater on a blustery day in Los Angeles, the photographer Sinna Nasseri captured their candid moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Halle Berry and Adrien Brody Recreate Famous Oscars Kiss
description: On the red carpet on Sunday night, Berry surprised Brody with a kiss, recalling one of the most memorable moments in Oscar history.
content: Plenty of kisses were shared on the Oscars red carpet on Sunday night — but none could have been as nostalgic as the moment Adrien Brody and Halle Berry locked lips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernard Mokam
title: A Black Studies Curriculum Is (Defiantly) Rolling Out in New York City
description: Educators are embracing rather than restricting discussions of race in schools. Leaders have said they’ll do so whether the Trump administration approves or not.
content: Late last fall at the Hugo Newman School in Harlem, two social studies teachers handed out pages of hip-hop lyrics to their seventh graders, and then flicked off the lights. The students appeared surprised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Trial of Music Teacher Accused of Sexual Abuse Stirs Painful Memories
description: Paul Geer, a former music instructor at a reform school in upstate New York, faced charges of sexual activity with children.
content: A courtroom can become a sort of time machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur and Jason Andrew
title: Figure Skating Stars Pay an Emotional Tribute to the D.C. Plane Crash Victims
description: Spectators, heavy with grief, packed Capital One Arena for the skating benefit.
content: At the end of his figure skating performance, when the last note of his parents’ favorite song played in an arena packed with spectators and heavy with sorrow, Maxim Naumov dropped to his knees at the center of the ice. He remained there for what seemed like forever, awash in a spotlight, looking lost and sobbing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Madeleine Ngo
title: Dozens of Government Technology Specialists Fired
description: The employees, who worked at the General Services Administration’s 18F unit, fixed technical problems and built products aimed at increasing efficiency for various federal agencies.
content: The Trump administration is terminating the jobs of dozens of technology specialists whose broad portfolio of projects across the government included the I.R.S.’s free tax filing software and passport services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and Matt Stevens
title: After Scandals, ‘Emilia Pérez,’ Nominated for 13 Oscars, Won 2
description: The Spanish-language musical from Netflix saw its grand hopes fizzle after derisive social media posts from its star resurfaced.
content: Just six weeks ago “Emilia Pérez” got 13 Oscar nominations, more than any other film this year. Its lead actress, Karla Sofía Gascón, made history by becoming the first openly trans actor to be nominated and the film, a musical about a Mexican cartel boss, was seen as a real contender to win the Academy Award for best picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: laxity
description: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word laxity has appeared 11 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 10 in The New York Times Magazine article “He Made a Daring Escape From China. Then His Real Troubles Began” by Nyrola Elimä and Ben Mauk. The article is about Hasan Imam, a refugee convicted of entering Thailand illegally in 2014:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Jeanna Smialek
title: Who Will Join Europe’s ‘Coalition of the Willing’ to Help Ukraine?
description: European leaders met in London to form a plan to help end the war in Ukraine. But even potential peacekeepers face political and economic hurdles.
content: Britain and France have promised to muster a “coalition of the willing” to secure a peace agreement between Ukraine and Russia. Now comes the acid test for Europe: How many countries will step up, and does that even matter, given Russia’s rejection of such a coalition as part of any settlement?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: Europe Faces a Huge Bill to Defend Ukraine. Investors Are Thrilled.
description: Europeans would need to ramp up military spending quickly, a notion that has set off a market rally, led by defense stocks.
content: European defense stocks soared on Monday after the region’s leaders vowed to take on “the heavy lifting” of defending Ukraine from Russia. The rally comes as the three-year-old war appears set to move into a new stage after an Oval Office blowup on Friday put President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on the outs with President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Iyad Abuheweila
title: With Cease-Fire Shaky, Israel and Hamas Weigh Diplomatic and Military Options
description: As the first phase of the truce in Gaza ends, the two sides are continuing negotiations but also preparing for a possible return to war.
content: When the cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hamas was announced in January, Israelis and Palestinians burst into simultaneous celebrations, optimistic after 15 months of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Daniel Dorsa
title: For L.A. Fire Victims, Two Words Bring Hope and a Little Normalcy: ‘Play Ball’
description: A Pacific Palisades youth baseball league has found a temporary home and, with lots of help, is reviving a sense of togetherness that was lost in January.
content: Boys and girls dressed in new uniforms put down their baseball gloves long enough to tackle plates of pancakes and sausages. Parents with coffee cups in hand greeted one another with hugs in the brisk morning air. There were familiar hallmarks of the opening day of baseball season: keynote speakers, the national anthem, red, white and blue balloons and a ceremonial first pitch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: One Hopped Turnstile, 9 Police Bullets, 4 People Shot. Does It Add Up?
description: New York’s subway has been flooded with patrols to prevent crime and stop fare evasion. One Sunday in Brooklyn, it all went wrong.
content: A man coming home from an overseas trip. Another on his way to work. A woman off to a celebratory dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arlene Hirst
title: 9 Stylish Products for Your Home
description: A sampling of recent home goods from veteran craftspeople.
content: Today, in a world overrun with technology, with artists still dealing with the isolation and preoccupations of the pandemic, we’re seeing a robust revival of handicrafts for the home. Below, some new objects from established leaders of the pack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: What Do We Want From Political Theater?
description: Playwrights and directors wrestle with how a piece of art can galvanize its audience.
content: In an era of vanishing cultural authority and ever-abbreviated attention spans, being called relevant is one of the best compliments a work of art can get. We’ve always celebrated art that seems to speak to our political and cultural moments, but these days — when the news relentlessly inundates us — art can feel like a surrogate, a response we’re unable to summon ourselves. Relevancy is less a compliment now than an expectation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Two Killed After Car Drives Into Crowd in Germany
description: The police in Mannheim, in the country’s southwest, said that the driver, a 40-year-old German citizen, had been arrested and that they did not believe he had a political motive.
content: An 83-year-old woman and a 54-year-old man were killed and 11 others were injured — five severely — when a man drove a car into a lunch-hour crowd in the southwestern German city of Mannheim on Monday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Achy Obejas
title: A Chabad House for a Growing Family
description: After a lengthy search, a rabbi and his wife decided the Bay Area was the right place to serve a large Jewish community.
content: In 2019, Rabbi Yanky Bell was on one of his annual pilgrimages to the Ohel, the resting place of Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson in Queens, New York, when he realized it was going to take him a while to write his petition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Cuomo’s First Mayoral Campaign Promise: A Plan to Tackle Affordability
description: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has jumped into the New York City mayoral race. His first proposal focuses on affordability.
content: When former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo joined the New York City mayoral race over the weekend, he reintroduced himself to New Yorkers after years out of the public eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Tan
title: Warren Buffett Rebukes Trump’s Tariffs Plan in CBS Interview: ‘Act of War’
description: The rebuke of President Trump’s tariff plans came just days before sweeping tariffs on Canada and Mexico were expected to go into effect.
content: Warren Buffett, the famed investor who runs the sprawling conglomerate Berkshire Hathaway, described tariffs as “an act of war” in an interview with CBS that aired on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Scrubs 8th Starship Rocket Test Flight
description: The company has made changes to the vehicle, part of which blew up over the Caribbean in January during the seventh test flight. An issue during the countdown halted Monday’s launch.
content: Starship — the spacecraft that Elon Musk says will one day take people to Mars — will try another day to carry out its eighth test flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: At Supreme Court, Mexico to Offer Culprit for Cartel Violence: Gun Makers
description: The dispute focuses on whether Mexico can hold U.S. manufacturers liable for gun violence and comes amid rising tensions between the countries.
content: Mexico’s president offered a warning last month in response to news that the Trump administration planned to designate drug cartels as terrorist groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Makoff
title: Trump’s Bad Plan to Make America Argentina Again
description: It was no surprise to Argentina watchers that Trump began his term by blocking cash flows and firing workers — exactly as Javier Milei’s government started doing a year ago.
content: President Trump, Elon Musk and President Javier Milei of Argentina have formed a special bond. Mr. Milei was the first foreign leader to meet with Mr. Trump days after he won the U.S. presidential election. Mr. Trump has called Mr. Milei his “favorite president.” And Mr. Musk has been in close contact with Mr. Milei’s government reform team since the U.S. election in November, if not before. So it was no surprise to Argentina watchers that Mr. Trump began his term by blocking government cash flows and firing workers, exactly as Mr. Milei’s government started doing a year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Adrien Brody Wins the Oscar for Best Actor
description: It is the second time he has triumphed in the category, this time for his performance in the epic “The Brutalist.”
content: Adrien Brody has won his second Oscar, this time for playing the fictional Hungarian architect László Tóth in the three-and-a-half-hour epic “The Brutalist.” The win on Sunday came 22 years after Brody received the best actor trophy for his work in “The Pianist,” which made him the youngest performer to ever receive that award. Both “The Brutalist” and “The Pianist” center on Holocaust survivor characters played by Brody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Why Demi Moore’s Oscar Loss to Mikey Madison Stings for Some Fans
description: Moore had been considered a favorite for her strong performance in “The Substance,” but Madison won for “Anora.”
content: Demi Moore snagged statuettes all through the awards season for her dynamic performance in “The Substance,” a film about the indignities women past 50 face in Hollywood. She was favored by many to win the Oscar for best actress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Senate Confirms Linda McMahon as Education Secretary
description: Ms. McMahon, who has little experience in private or public schools, will take over a department that President Trump has already begun to dismantle.
content: The Senate voted along party lines on Monday to confirm Linda McMahon as the nation’s next education secretary, putting the former pro-wrestling executive in charge of an agency that the Trump administration wants to eliminate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Mild Shaking Felt in Los Angeles After 3.9-Magnitude Earthquake
description: The epicenter was about a mile from North Hollywood. Little to no damage was expected, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
content: A 3.9-magnitude earthquake caused mild shaking in and near the Hollywood neighborhood of Los Angeles late Sunday, the United States Geological Survey said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande Open the Oscars With ‘Defying Gravity’ Performance
description: The stars also paid tribute to “The Wizard of Oz,” with Grande singing “Over the Rainbow,” and “The Wiz,” with Erivo singing “Home.”
content: The stars of “Wicked” Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo opened the Oscars with a spirited tribute to the cinematic versions of Oz, culminating in a rendition in “Defying Gravity” from their nominated film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Khalil Fong, Hong Kong Singer-Songwriter, Dies at 41
description: Singing in both Mandarin and English, he brought a soul and R&B sensibility to Chinese pop.
content: Khalil Fong, a Hong Kong singer-songwriter who infused a soul and R&B sensibility into Chinese pop songs, died on Feb. 21. He was 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Morgan Freeman Paid Tribute to Gene Hackman at Oscars
description: Freeman and Hackman, who was found dead last week at the age of 95, appeared together in the 1992 western “Unforgiven.”
content: Morgan Freeman honored Gene Hackman at the Academy Awards on Sunday, opening the telecast’s in memoriam segment by saying that the film community had “lost a giant.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Trump Official Makes Video With a Message: Kill Congestion Pricing
description: The secretary of transportation, Sean Duffy, posted an unusual video that features interviews with five men who are opposed to New York’s tolling program.
content: The Trump administration has vowed to kill congestion pricing in New York City. Now officials have taken the unusual step of making a man-on-the-street video to demonstrate what they say is public opposition to the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: The Fairy Tale Night of Sean Baker, Director of Dreams Gone Awry
description: Baker’s four Oscars for “Anora” are validation of his sensitive portrayals of people on the margins who always seem to come up short.
content: Sean Baker came equipped with extra speeches, and that was wise: On the night of the Oscars, he wound up onstage four times to receive four statues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: Can the Media’s Right to Pursue the Powerful Survive Trump’s Second Term?
description: New York Times v. Sullivan and other landmark Supreme Court decisions protect the press’s ability to investigate public figures. But a growing right-wing movement seeks to overturn them.
content: In any given year, the United States Supreme Court hears only 80 or so cases. That means that — in a nation with more than 1.3 million attorneys — the group of lawyers who get to argue before the nine justices is an exclusive club. For years, it was Roy Katriel’s dream to gain access to that club. He would regularly trawl through the dockets of the country’s 13 federal appeals courts, looking for cases to latch onto that seemed ripe for Supreme Court review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: A Celebration of The Washington Post’s Past as It Faces an Uncertain Future
description: A premiere for a documentary about Katharine Graham, the longtime publisher, had people talking about changes at the paper, and in Washington.
content: On Sunday evening, as well-heeled guests trickled out of a screening of “Becoming Katharine Graham,” a documentary on the fabled former Washington Post publisher, they couldn’t help but remark on how much has changed at the paper, and in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The White Lotus’ Season 3, Episode 3: The Snake Show
description: The guests are getting restless, and Mike White seems ready to start making messes.
content: In last week’s “The White Lotus,” the three gal-pals — who are supposed to be on a bonding trip in Thailand — took turns pairing off and, in insinuating whispers, tearing each other apart. Kate and Jaclyn muttered anxiously about Laurie’s draining divorce, stalled career and delinquent daughter. Kate and Laurie took shots at Jaclyn’s cosmetic procedures and sham marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Hegseth Revives the Old Name of Another Military Base
description: The base’s name was changed to Fort Moore in 2023 as part of a bipartisan effort to eliminate military honors bestowed on Confederate officers.
content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth continued his efforts to revive the Confederate names of military bases, announcing on Monday that he is re-renaming Fort Moore, whose previous name honored the confederate general Henry Benning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Day Care Owner Sentenced to 45 Years in Fentanyl Death of 1-Year-Old
description: Grei Mendez tried to delete thousands of messages while she was being questioned by police investigators after a child died in her care. Many were recovered, and they were damning.
content: After fentanyl sickened three toddlers and killed a fourth at the Divino Niño day care, its proprietor, Grei Mendez, professed to be caught up in a bewildering catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2025 Oscars
description: There was plenty to take in, including a “Wicked” opener, Conan O’Brien gags, and memorable speeches both good and bad. And people watching on Hulu saw almost all of it.
content: When it was announced that Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo would perform at the Oscars, it was assumed they would sing something from “Wicked,” the film for which they were both nominated. They did, of course. It would be silly to pass up that opportunity. But the women also paid tribute to previous cinematic versions of Oz, showing how Hollywood had imagined L. Frank Baum’s world through the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Su and Alexander Stockton
title: Meanwhile … This Is What the Democrats Are Doing?
description: Donald Trump is already wreaking havoc — even on his own supporters. But don’t worry. Democrats have a winning strategy to beat him. Or not.
content: Democrats are out of power across the federal government. They’re confronting an antagonistic Supreme Court, a Congress that is almost totally abdicating its power, the wealthiest man in the world wielding a chain saw, and a president with nothing to lose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Scherstuhl
title: A Jazz Quintet Bubbling With Good Vibes? Meet the Women of Artemis.
description: The pianist Renee Rosnes formed the group in 2016, and it has evolved into a five-piece drawn from different nations and generations with a common goal.
content: The multinational, intergenerational jazz quintet Artemis is, as they might say, bubbling. Last fall, it topped Downbeat magazine’s reader’s poll as jazz group of the year for the second time running. On Friday, the band released its third album, “Arboresque,” which captures both the hard-bop strut of the most beloved 1960s recordings by its storied label, Blue Note Records, as well as Artemis’s own fresh take on jazz tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Pope Experiences Another Setback With Respiratory Crises
description: The Vatican said that Monday’s two crises were caused by a significant accumulation of mucus in his bronchial tubes.
content: Pope Francis had two acute respiratory crises on Monday, the Vatican said, stoking further concerns about the health of the 88-year old pontiff, who has been hospitalized in Rome in serious condition for more than two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2,500 Rentals in Los Angeles
description: A one-bedroom condo in Los Feliz, a stand-alone cottage in Silver Lake, and a unit in a master-planned community in Woodland Hills.
content: To provide a resource for those displaced by the Los Angeles fires, this edition of “What You Get” focuses on rentals rather than properties for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Truths to Remember in a Time of Lies
description: Chaos and disorientation are the goals here. But we know what’s going on behind the curtain.
content: The brickbats are meant to knock us senseless. Blow after blow, they bludgeon us. Who could possibly keep them straight?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘My 10,000 Hours’: The Diaries That Made Helen Garner a Writer
description: “How to End a Story” collects three volumes of the Australian novelist’s self-conscious, sometimes harrowing journals.
content: The Australian writer Helen Garner’s fiction has long been prized by people whose taste I trust. Yet when I’ve picked up her novels, I’ve bounced off them, like a spacecraft that has botched re-entry into the earth’s atmosphere. Every reader must have a writer or two like this, ones they sense they should like but do not. Garner’s work has seemed, in my brief encounters with it, thin and in want of polish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Man Pleads Guilty in Illinois Fourth of July Parade Shooting
description: The guilty plea came just as his murder trial was about to start, for an attack in a Chicago suburb in 2022 that killed seven people.
content: The man accused of killing seven people with a high-powered rifle during a Fourth of July parade in suburban Chicago in 2022 pleaded guilty on Monday, just as opening statements were expected to begin in his murder trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Bonisteel
title: Forget the Mardi Gras Beads. This Year’s Best Catch Is a Cookbook.
description: Of all the gifts thrown at the New Orleans parades, one of the newest and most unusual is a collection of South Asian family recipes.
content: They throw lots of things at the Carnival parades in New Orleans: plastic beads and stuffed animals, glittered shoes and doubloons, light-up swords and toilet plungers. But cookbooks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: Where to Stream the 2025 Oscar Winners, From ‘Anora’ to ‘Flow’
description: Most of the awarded films, including the winner of best picture, can be watched at home. Here’s a guide to catch up.
content: In a resounding win for American independent film, “Anora,” Sean Baker’s rambunctious comedy-drama about the marriage between a Brighton Beach sex worker and the son of a Russian oligarch, won five Oscars, including one for its lead actress, Mikey Madison, and a record-tying four for Baker, who took home statuettes for picture, director, editing and his original screenplay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Hal Hirshorn, Artist of Otherworldly Photos and Paintings, Dies at 60
description: A ubiquitous presence in New York’s art world, he also existed outside it, using 19th-century techniques to create ethereal, haunting images.
content: Hal Hirshorn, an artist known for his ubiquity around New York City’s cultural scene, who nevertheless managed to exist outside its manic commercial hustle, using antique cameras and homemade paints to produce haunting photographs and landscape paintings, died on Feb. 4. He was 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Trump Made English the Official Language. What Does It Mean for the Country?
description: President Trump’s executive order puts his “America first” stamp onto the nation’s speech. But the effect might be muted.
content: President Trump’s executive order making English the official language of the United States reached into history to argue its case, noting that the country’s founding documents were written in English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: See the Looks From Vanity Fair’s Red Carpet
description: Jeff Bezos, Zoe Saldaña, Lizzo and more stars were on their way into the Vanity Fair Oscars party.
content: Wardrobe changes are old hat in Hollywood, but on Oscar night, when opining on a celebrity’s choice of attire is sport, changing outfits becomes big news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Trump and Politics Were Largely Absent From the Oscars
description: The host, Conan O’Brien, avoided politics in his monologue but later made a pointed joke about an “Anora” character who stood up to a powerful Russian.
content: Washington was an entire country away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld and Renaud Philippe
title: Snowy Trails, Cozy Inns: Skiing Town to Town in Quebec
description: A new series of ski tours in the Laurentian Mountains combine rigorous days of cross-country skiing with overnight stays (and meals) at local inns.
content: Amid light snow, I skied out of the town of Ste.-Adèle, in the Laurentian Mountains of Quebec, and headed to Prévost, eight miles away. Only a few minutes earlier, I had walked out of Au Clos Rolland, a historic inn where I’d spent the previous night dining on a decadent three-course meal and resting up from a day of cross-country skiing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: Sean Baker’s Oscars Battle Cry (and Mine): Don’t Abandon the Big Screen
description: The director of the best picture winner, “Anora,” urged viewers to keep seeing films in theaters. Our critic hopes the industry listens, and that Baker keeps his independence.
content: Two minor quakes hit Los Angeles Sunday night, and I like to think that they were cosmically connected. The second earthquake was a small rattler (3.9) centered in the San Fernando Valley, just north of where the first quake hit inside the Dolby Theater when “Anora” won best picture. A pleasurable romp about an exotic dancer who runs off with the son of a Russian oligarch, “Anora” is the latest of several movies that its writer-director, Sean Baker, has made on sex industry workers. The first one that Baker did on the same topic was “Starlet,” a wistful, charming 2012 drama set in the Valley, long the center of the pornography industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Alexandra Stevenson
title: Trump Turns Up Trade Pressure on China After Beijing Fails to Come Running
description: China is still cautiously trying to figure out what Trump wants. The president has threatened big tariffs in response to the inaction.
content: When President Trump threatened tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China in January, saying those countries needed to do more to stop the flow of drugs and migrants into the United States, Canadian and Mexican officials raced to Washington, bearing charts and videos detailing their efforts to toughen their borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Harris and Jennifer Livingston
title: Why Does Every Play Seem Political Now?
description: Theater about current events — both literally and abstractly — is changing the conversation between playwrights, directors and their audiences.
content: IT’S ALWAYS BEEN a good argument starter to contend that all theater is political, even if the claim sometimes depends on stretching the definition of “political” to its vaguest outer limits. For one thing, unlike movies or television or books, theater requires you to leave your home and participate in the creation of an ad hoc collective, albeit frequently with the irritation that proximity to strangers can engender. And during periods when the people in charge belong to a party that, for instance, evinces loathing for the funding of art and artists, choosing to go to the theater can feel like a political act in itself. That’s all the truer if the experience challenges you to assess where you stand (or sit) in relation not only to whatever is being said or done onstage but to all of the reactions bursting forth around you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Eighteen European leaders gathered yesterday in London to repair Ukraine’s fractured relationship with the U.S., with Britain and France assembling a “coalition of the willing” to develop a plan for ending the war with Russia. The leaders also pledged to bolster support for Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: M. Paul Friedberg, Landscape Architect Who Celebrated the City, Dies at 93
description: He made his mark as a designer of experimental playgrounds in New York City and then used the same ideas to reinvent urban parks across the country.
content: M. Paul Friedberg, a landscape architect whose playgrounds, pocket parks and plazas transformed once-gritty areas of New York City, using familiar urban materials to do so, died on Feb. 15 in Manhattan. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Kroger C.E.O. Resigns After Board’s Personal Conduct Investigation
description: The grocery chain said it had investigated its chief executive, Rodney McMullen, and found that his actions were “inconsistent” with its business ethics policy.
content: The grocery chain Kroger said on Monday that its chief executive, Rodney McMullen, had resigned after a board investigation of his personal conduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Conan O’Brien Pokes Fun at Top Movies and Stars in Oscars Monologue
description: The comedian joked about the length of “The Brutalist” and the “Emilia Pérez” actress Karla Sofia Gascón’s offensive social media posts.
content: Conan O’Brien was literally born to host the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Lech Walesa, Polish Labor Leader Who Fought U.S.S.R.’s Power, Joins in Horrified Letter to Trump
description: He and former Polish political prisoners voiced “horror and disgust” at President Trump’s scolding of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last week, saying it reminded them of encounters with bullying Communist-era officials.
content: Lech Walesa, the leader of Poland’s Solidarity movement, which helped end Moscow’s grip on Eastern Europe at the end of the Cold War, joined with former Polish political prisoners on Monday to send an impassioned letter to President Trump voicing “horror and disgust” at his scolding of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last week, saying it reminded them of their encounters with bullying Communist-era officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, Simon Romero and Ian Austen
title: Trump Will Impose 25% Tariffs on Canada and Mexico
description: President Trump said he would impose levies on America’s largest trading partners Tuesday. Industries are preparing for the worst.
content: President Trump said Monday that sweeping tariffs on Canada and Mexico would go into effect on Tuesday, stating in remarks at the White House there was no chance for a last-minute deal to avert the levies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Tuesday Briefing: Trump’s Tariffs Set to Take Effect
description: Plus, Sean Baker’s big Oscar wins.
content: President Trump’s threats to impose stiff tariffs on goods imported from Canada, Mexico and China are expected to become a reality today. Trump said yesterday that there was no chance for a deal to avert them. Company executives and foreign officials scrambled to prepare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Strong Winds Force Cancellation of Some Mardi Gras Parades in Louisiana
description: Jefferson Parish canceled its parades, and officials in New Orleans were warily watching the Tuesday forecast.
content: Extreme winds and possible storms expected on Tuesday have forced the cancellation of Mardi Gras parades in Jefferson Parish, La., as officials in neighboring New Orleans moved up parade starting times because of the forecast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig and Vik Jolly
title: A Scenic California Rail Line Sits on an Eroding Cliff. Where Should the Tracks Go?
description: In the city of Del Mar, near San Diego, most agree the train tracks must move off eroding bluffs. But debate over its new route has stalled the project while climate change raises the risks.
content: Perched atop craggy bluffs in a beachside city north of San Diego, a railroad line offers passengers a sweeping view of the Pacific Coast. But the ground beneath it is crumbling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal El Kadhi and Sasha Kelly
title: Classic Coats Get a Fresh Update
description: Pops of pink and yellow, and hints of mesh, give a playful edge to traditional tailored outerwear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Released From Hamas Captivity, a Hostage Finds His Family Gone
description: Eli Sharabi gave himself up on Oct. 7, 2023, hoping to save his wife and daughters. After some 500 days in the tunnels of Gaza, he emerged to learn that they had been killed.
content: Hollow-eyed and emaciated after nearly 500 days in captivity in Gaza, Eli Sharabi stood on a podium flanked by masked Hamas gunmen, unaware of what most Israelis already knew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Nina Westervelt
title: Inside Vanity Fair’s 2025 Oscars Party
description: Conan O’Brien, Zoe Saldaña, Timothée Chalamet and more packed the annual post-awards bash for burgers, cocktails and victory laps.
content: Zoe Saldaña stood in the middle of Vanity Fair’s Oscars after-party Sunday night, holding an In-N-Out burger in one hand and her best supporting actress statuette in the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Should There Be an Age Minimum for Anti-Aging Skin Care Products?
description: California proposed a bill that would make it illegal for companies to sell such products to shoppers under 18 years old. Should lawmakers pass it?
content: We’d like to thank the students from Joel Neden’s English class at New Paltz High School in New Paltz, N.Y., for suggesting this article and many of the questions for discussion below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: A Store That Gets How People Dress Now
description: The Archivist Store in Paris has become a destination for those who want a mix of vintage high fashion, faded streetwear and functional outdoorsy gear.
content: It was men’s fashion week in Paris, and the Archivist Store was as busy as Gare du Nord. That is, if the train depot were frequented solely by people who could tell a mere North Face jacket from a North Face Purple Label one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: ‘Deli Boys,’ Plus 9 Things to Watch on TV this Week
description: A new Hulu comedy premieres, “The Righteous Gemstones” are back and “The Traitors” wraps up its third season.
content: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that air or stream this week, March 3-9. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The ‘Disgraceful Display’ in the Oval Office
description: Readers react to the heated meeting between Presidents Trump and Zelensky. Also: Donald Trump’s lies; money for lab scientists; The New Yorker at 100.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Gene Hackman Was Their Most Famous Neighbor. They Rarely Saw Him.
description: Before they were found dead at home last week, the movie star and his wife, Betsy Arakawa, lived an increasingly isolated life in New Mexico.
content: He had two Oscars, adoring fans and four decades of acting to his credit. He won over critics, befriended celebrities and starred in scores of films watched by millions of moviegoers. But for the past two decades, Gene Hackman found solace at the end of a quiet cul-de-sac where few neighbors ever even saw him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
title: Trump Faces Blowback Over Plans for Crypto Reserve
description: Digital assets like Bitcoin rallied on the president’s backing for a strategic holding, but even some conservatives and industry backers disapproved.
content: Cryptocurrencies are again riding high, after President Trump announced that he would create a national crypto reserve with five tokens, including three lesser-known and highly volatile ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W. Ian Lipkin and Ralph Baric
title: Recent Virus Research Should Raise the Alarm
description: Research with pandemic potential needs the utmost precautions.
content: There’s a central question that many scientists face: How can scientific discoveries drive humanity’s progress without posing a dire risk to it? As virus experts, we’re committed to research that uncovers pandemic threats and helps protect people from them. But we are concerned about how some scientists are experimenting with viruses in ways that could put all of us in harm’s way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Peter Baker, Will Reid, Mooj Zadie, Liz O. Baylen, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Fallout From Zelensky and Trump’s Oval Office Meltdown
description: A clash between presidents, and its consequences.
content: On Friday, President Trump and Vice President JD Vance berated President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in an explosive televised Oval Office meeting and abruptly cut short a visit that was meant to help coordinate a plan for peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joy Dong and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: The ‘Leniency’ Trap: How China’s Plea System Gives Prosecutors More Power
description: China has embraced a plea deal system, but lawyers and scholars fear that it is being abused to further erode individual rights — and for shakedowns.
content: When Son Jun-ho, a key midfielder for South Korea’s World Cup soccer team, signed with a Chinese club, he was an indication of China’s ambition to dominate the world’s most popular sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Was That Gum He Tossed From the Oscars Stage?
description: Adrien Brody had one of the strangest moments of this year’s Oscars. And it wasn’t his five-minute speech.
content: Adrien Brody was en route to the stage at the Dolby Theatre on Sunday night to collect his Oscar for best actor when it appeared to dawn on him that he had forgotten to do something — something important.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Economic Upheaval and Plans to Retaliate: Canada Braces for Tariffs
description: President Trump’s plan to apply 25 percent tariffs on Canadian exports is set to start on Tuesday. They would deal a brutal blow to Canada’s economy.
content: It is not an exit anyone would have expected. Justin Trudeau will end his final days as Canada’s prime minister with the country tossed into economic turmoil if President Trump follows through on his plan Tuesday to impose 25 percent tariffs on Canadian exports.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: The ‘S.N.L.’ Hosts Who Give 110%
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 3, 2025
content: “And I had to understand, ‘They don’t like me, they’re just pitching me ideas for these skits.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sinna Nasseri
title: On the Ground at the Governors Ball 2025 Oscars Party
description: Mikey Madison, Zoe Saldaña, Kieran Culkin and other winners celebrated at the official Academy Awards after-party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 6 Movies and Shows Before They Leave Netflix in March
description: A great Park Chan-wook film and a hilarious British satire are among the great titles leaving for U.S. subscribers this month.
content: This month’s noteworthy Netflix departures in the United States include a chilling indie, a South Korean classic, two honest-to-goodness great popcorn flicks and a very funny skewering of England’s most famous family. (Dates reflect the first day titles are unavailable and are subject to change.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Said Tariffs Are Coming
description: Also, Cuomo entered the New York mayoral race as a front-runner. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: President Trump said today that he would impose a 25 percent fee on all goods imported into the U.S. from Mexico and Canada, along with an additional 10 percent levy atop existing fees on goods from China. The tariffs, which are set to take effect at midnight and target America’s three largest trading partners, would be Trump’s most wide-reaching trade action to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Maya Tekeli and Chris Buckley
title: For Greenland’s Minerals, the Harsh Reality Behind the Glittering Promise
description: There is excitement about the potentially lucrative resources scattered around the island, especially the rare earths. But extreme weather, fired-up environmentalists and other factors have tempered hopes of a bonanza.
content: More than a decade ago, Canadian miners prospecting for diamonds in western Greenland saw on the horizon a huge white hump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: What Big-Business Leaders, Including Democrats, Say Privately About Trump
description: Behind closed doors, many top executives voice support for the new administration.
content: Over lunch last week with a friend of mine — a major technology investor who has been an ardent Democrat — the talk quickly turned to politics. Like many businessmen, he refuses to air his views publicly to avoid drawing fire. In private, he’s more forthcoming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: John Casey, Novelist of Salty, Rough-Hewn Characters, Dies at 86
description: He won a National Book Award for “Spartina,” beating out novels by Amy Tan and E.L. Doctorow. A longtime professor, he lived for a time without electricity on an island.
content: John Casey, a writer of lyric yet taut prose in novels, essays and short stories who won the National Book Award in 1989 for “Spartina,” the story of a rough-hewn fisherman that reviewers called the best American story of nautical life since Hemingway’s “The Old Man and the Sea,” died on Feb. 22 at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 632
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, March 4, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martine Thompson
title: When a Marriage Proposal Is the Deal Breaker
description: For some couples, a marriage proposal can mark the end of a relationship. Experts share tips on how to determine if you should move forward with an engagement and why it’s OK to say no.
content: When Geraldine Oluoha went out to dinner with her then-boyfriend just before her 21st birthday in August 2023, she had no idea the evening would become a life-altering moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: ‘I’m Still Here’ Wins Best International Feature
description: The Brazilian film focuses on a real activist whose husband disappeared after a military raid.
content: The Brazilian film “I’m Still Here,” based on the true story of an activist whose dissident politician husband disappeared at the hands of a military government, won the Academy Award for best international feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller
title: Democrats Invite Fired Federal Workers to Trump’s Congressional Address
description: The move comes as lawmakers hear from constituents over President Trump’s and Elon Musk’s efforts to slash federal spending and cull the civil service ranks.
content: Rather than boycott President Trump’s address to a joint session of Congress, some Democratic lawmakers are inviting former federal workers to the speech on Tuesday as a way to protest the mass firings and funding cuts that have defined Mr. Trump’s first month back in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: How Tariffs on China Could Make Stuffed Animals and Tonka Trucks More Expensive
description: A trade show for toys, most of which are made in China, showcased an industry, underneath the fun, rattled by President Trump’s higher tariffs.
content: At the biggest toy industry trade show in the Western Hemisphere this weekend, toy makers, as usual, displayed seemingly endless rows of stuffed animals, action figures and puzzles, hoping to entice retailers to pick their products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Running for N.Y. Mayor, Cuomo Also Has a Message for National Democrats
description: Attacking the Democratic Party’s leadership as he declared his candidacy to run the nation’s largest city, he clearly had a wider audience, and his own ambitions, in mind.
content: In declaring his candidacy for mayor of New York, former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo painted a picture of a city in trouble, besieged by crime, homelessness and menace, above and below ground. For all these problems, he blamed a central culprit: the failed leadership of the Democratic Party, of which he has been a fixture for most of his adult life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,354
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, March 4, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martín González Gómez and Alicia Parlapiano
title: How Each Senator Voted to Confirm Linda McMahon as Education Secretary
description: The Senate confirmed Ms. McMahon to lead the Education Department by a party-line vote of 51 to 45.
content: The Senate confirmed Ms. McMahon to lead the Education Department by a party-line vote of 51 to 45.

description: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.

title: Read the Memo
description: Nicholas Enrich, acting assistant administrator for global health at U.S.A.I.D., spelled out projections for human health following cuts to foreign aid. Mr. Enrich was placed on administrative leave over the weekend.
content: Nicholas Enrich, acting assistant administrator for global health at U.S.A.I.D., spelled out projections for human health following cuts to foreign aid. Mr. Enrich was placed on administrative leave over the weekend.

author: By Marc Santora, Lara Jakes, Andrew E. Kramer, Marco Hernandez and Liubov Sholudko
title: A Thousand Snipers in the Sky: The New War in Ukraine
description: Drones have changed the war in Ukraine, with soldiers adapting off-the-shelf models and swarming the front lines.
content: Drones have changed the war in Ukraine, with soldiers adapting off-the-shelf models and swarming the front lines.

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Well Do You Know State Capitals? Or Books Set in Them?
description: If you still remember the 50 U.S. state capital cities from memorizing them in school, you’ll do well on this week’s literary quiz.
content: If you still remember the 50 U.S. state capital cities from memorizing them in school, you’ll do well on this week’s literary quiz.

author: By Ang Li
title: Wildfires Continue to Burn in South Carolina
description: Heavy smoke blanketed the Carolina Forest area, a community just west of Myrtle Beach, where the largest fire raged across 1,600 acres, fire officials said.
content: Heavy smoke blanketed the Carolina Forest area, a community just west of Myrtle Beach, where the largest fire raged across 1,600 acres, fire officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Su and Alexander Stockton
title: How Democrats’ Bad Messaging Could Ensure Another Republican Win
description: Donald Trump is already wreaking havoc — even on his own supporters. But don’t worry. Democrats have a winning strategy to beat him. Or not.
content: Donald Trump is already wreaking havoc — even on his own supporters. But don’t worry. Democrats have a winning strategy to beat him. Or not.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Oscars Red Carpet Filled With Star-Studded Looks
description: The red carpet at the 97th Academy Awards was filled with celebrities whose sartorial choices spanned the color spectrum, and political statements were made with small accessories.
content: The red carpet at the 97th Academy Awards was filled with celebrities whose sartorial choices spanned the color spectrum, and political statements were made with small accessories.

author: By Kyle Buchanan, Gabriel Blanco, Chevaz Clarke and Laura Salaberry
title: Highlights From The 2025 Oscars
description: “Anora” director Sean Baker tied with Walt Disney for most Oscars won in a single night, and the International Film category showcased a drastic flip in one-time favorite “Emilia Pérez.”
content: “Anora” director Sean Baker tied with Walt Disney for most Oscars won in a single night, and the International Film category showcased a drastic flip in one-time favorite “Emilia Pérez.”
